c74object.name: cage.scale
c74object.description: Outputs the notes forming a given scale, within a certain pitch range.

inlet.description: The lower bound can be set either as a cents value or a pitch.
The upper bound can be set either as a cents value or a pitch.

outlet.description: The plain llll of cents of the notes composing the scale.

objarg.name: lower_bound
objarg.description: The first optional argument sets the initial lower bound for the scale (in cents or pitch)

objarg.name: upper_bound
objarg.description: The second optional argument sets the initial upper bound for the scale (in cents or pitch)

objarg.name: chord_type_or_pattern
objarg.description: The third optional arguments sets the initial scale type (if it is a symbol) or the explicit scale pattern (if it is an llll). See the symbol and llll methods to know more.

method.name: bang
method.description: Output the scale obtained from the most recently received input data.

method.name: llll
method.description:
An llll in the first or second inlet is expected to be a single number (working exactly like the number message) or a note name (working exactly like the symbol message).
An llll in the third inlet, can either be a single symbol (working like the symbol message), or a pattern of intervals (in cents or in pitches) defining the scale. For instance, 100 200 100 200 100 200 100 200 builds the semitone-tone octophonic scale This pattern starts from a given base note, set via the base attribute. For instance, if the base note is a G, this scale would yield: G, Ab, Bb, B, C#, D, E, F, G, Ab...

method.name: number
method.description:
A number in the first inlet sets the lower bound for the scale range, and outputs the scale as a plain llll of midicents.
A number in the second inlet sets the upper bound for the scale.

method.name: symbol
method.digest: Set range boundary or scale name, output result
method.description:
A symbol in the first inlet is expected to be the note name of the lower bound for the scale range; the scale is then output as a plain llll of midicents.
A symbol in the second inlet is expected to be the note name of the upper bound for the scale.
A symbol in the third inlet is interpreted as a scale name, such as CM or F#m. Each scale name is composed by the juxtaposition of the note name (in anglosaxon style, e.g. C, Fb...) and a suffix, determining the scale type: either M (major) or m (minor). Any other scale can be obtained by setting a custom pattern (see the llll method).

attribute.name: base
attribute.description: Sets the base note (in pitch or cents) for custom scale. Scales defined by an llll pattern (see llll method) start from a given base note, set via this attribute, which can either be a number (identifying the midicents of the base note) or a symbol (identifying the note name, in either latin or anglosaxon syntax).

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

c74object.discussion: The scale can be defined either via a chord symbol (such as CM or Fmaj7) or via explicit midicent pattern (such as 100 200 100 200 100 200 100 200). See the llll method in third inlet to know more.
